The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

div.head: AN HISTORY OF THE Ri≈øe, Growth, Reign, Supports, and ≈øodain fatal Foyl of POPERY, &c.
div.p:
RAiling Accu≈øation was ≈øuch a thing as Michael the Arch-Angel dur≈øt not u≈øe again≈øt the Devil, (Jud. 9.) But when Men ≈øpeak Evil, in ≈øuch ca≈øes by ≈øurmi≈øe only, of things which they know not, and that of Dignities, (ver. 10. 8.) Then woe unto Them, (≈øaith the Apo≈øtle) for that they are in the way of Cain, and are greedily running after the error of Balaam for reward, and are threatned that They ≈øhall peri≈øh in the gain≈øaying of Korah, (ver. 11.) The≈øe are ≈øpots in our feasts. Now in all National and Publick Affairs, it is the Duty of all good Chri≈øtians to perform all Offices and acts of duty with utmo≈øt Charity, as They tender the wellfare of the common good of Their Country wherein They inhabit: But of all ≈øuch National Affairs, none call louder for acts of pure Charity, than the Election of grave and wi≈øe Magi≈øtrates and Councellors, who are to ≈øit at the Helm, in order to manage the great Councils of a whole Kingdom. Wherefore to hear of Schi≈øms and Factions in ≈øuch ca≈øes, ≈øavors
exceedingly of the ≈øpirit and temper of Cain, who ≈ølew his Brother, and why? But becau≈øe his own works were evil, and his Brothers good, (Joh. 3.12.). Was it any wrong to the City of London, that it had yet More men of Reputation, to ≈øtand as Candidates to be Elected Members of Parliament, to ≈øerve for that mo≈øt famous and Metropolitan City of the Kingdom, and that over and above, and be≈øides what had ≈øerved immediately before? Surely no, but rather it is for the glory of that Noble City, that it hath ≈øuch variety of Choice. But was it ≈øo, that the Reputation and fame, of the wi≈ødom and vertue of the New Members, did make the loude≈øt noi≈øe above the Old Ones; yet why ≈øhould this breed ≈øo much the more envy? What needed Malitious Lies to be ≈øtrown into the Vulgar Ears, in order to ≈øuppre≈øs the noi≈øe of Vertue and Honour? Or what needed the Clamours of Anabapti≈øts, Presbyterians, Quakers, and Congregational-Men, that cry'd down the choice by ≈øuch Men as They ≈øaid, [would bring in King James again to Reign over us?] That Popery is one of the greate≈øt Annoyances that can befall this Kingdom, and the bittere≈øt Pill that can be pre≈øcribed for the Subjects, here, to take, is a Doctrine pa≈øt Di≈øpute. And to be an In≈øtrument to introduce ≈øuch Members of Parliament, as ≈øhall purpo≈øely endeavour to ≈øet up ≈øuch a Prince as certainly will E≈øtabli≈øh Popery in all that ever He can do, ≈øavors neither of Charity towards this Church or Kingdom of England, nor of Piety towards God. What King James hath done, is too well known. And we cannot ≈øay, but the Sin of the People, hath ju≈øtly de≈øerved all that hath befallen us; and not only ≈øo, but al≈øo the whole of all tho≈øe fears upon us, that they ≈øhould have come to pa≈øs even as we feared. And what the wrath of God, becau≈øe of our Sins, hath yet behind, to throw upon us, God knows! And we may ju≈øtly dread! However, it becomes not us to ≈øpeak evil of Kings, e≈øpecially ≈øo nearly Related unto ≈øuch, by who≈øe means we have received good things. Leaving therefore that wickedne≈øs to be acted only by the wicked and devili≈øh Railers; let us only for the good of this Church and Kingdom, make a ≈øtrict inquiry out of
the Publick and Weekly Gazettes, who and what They were, who were the greate≈øt promoters of all the≈øe Evil things, for the ≈øake of which we cry out ≈øo much again≈øt King James.

On February the 6th. 1684. King Charles the II. Died. And on the ≈øame day was Proclaimed James the II. as His only Brother, and Heir. And afterwards King James the Second having confirmed all Officers in Place as were before, came into the Privy-Council Chamber, and ≈øpake, ≈øaying to this effect as follows; [That He would follow His Brothers Example in Clemency and Tenderne≈øs to His People. That He would endeavour to pre≈øerve the Government both in Church and State, as then it was by Law E≈øtabli≈øhed. That He would always take care to Defend and Support the Church of England. That He would never invade any Man's Property. That He would go as far as any Man in pre≈øerving the Defence of this Nation in all its ju≈øt Rights and Liberties.]
This Speech by the King's Command was made Publick. How He hath kept His Royal Word, God knows, it becometh not me to ≈øay.

On February the 11th. came in the fir≈øt Addre≈øs from Port≈ømouth Garri≈øon, and the Society of Lincolns Inn, Congratulating His Maje≈øties Acce≈ø≈øion to the Throne, and promi≈øing Obedience. And henceforwards came in more February the 4th. from Ip≈øwich: The Ea≈øt India Company, Merchants of the Levant: The Bi≈øhop and Clergy of London: The Inner-Temple, Middle-Temple London, Grays-Inn, Port≈ømouth Corporation, Wells in Somer≈øet≈øhire, We≈øtmin≈øter, &c. And on the ≈øame day was King Charles the Second Buried Privately at We≈øtmin≈øter in the Evening.

Henceforward followed Addre≈ø≈øes from all Counties and mo≈øt of the Great Towns all over England, Scotland and Ireland, and from mo≈øt Parts of His Maje≈øties Dominions. And Amba≈ø≈øadors from all the Neighbouring Kingdoms and States did Congratulate.

On April the 23d. 1685. King James the Second, with Mary His Queen, were both Crowned at Westminster with great Pomp and State; at what time His Maje≈øty took
His Oath to do all things according to what he had afore promi≈øed, on the day he came fir≈øt to be King.

Now, pre≈øently after His Maje≈øty came to the Crown, He began to ≈øhew Him≈øelf a Papist, and openly went to Ma≈øs at His Palace at St. James's. Notwith≈øtanding which, infinite numbers of Addre≈ø≈øes of Congratulation were continually coming in unto His Coronation, and after.

On the 23d. of April al≈øo met the Parliament called in Scotland. Which being Met, did greatly Congratulate His Maje≈øties Acce≈ø≈øion to the Throne, with promi≈øes of much Obedience. And this Parliament made an Act to confirm and ≈øecure the Prote≈øtant Religion as it was then E≈øtabli≈øhed, by Arch-bi≈øhops and Bi≈øhops; and did promi≈øe in a Letter to the King, to do their be≈øt to Extirpate Fanataci≈øm, as in tho≈øe days They counted and called the Presbyterian Government.

On May the 23d. the Engli≈øh Parliament Met at Westminster. At what time His Maje≈øty renewed His Promi≈øes made at His fir≈øt coming to the Crown, viz. To maintain the Church of England and the Property of the Subject. And withal gave notice of Argyle Landed in Scotland. And immediately the Lords fir≈øt, and then the Commons, were thankful for the King's Speech, and promi≈øed to a≈ø≈øi≈øt him again≈øt Argyle; who coming in well furni≈øhed with Armour, Ships and Men, as his ca≈øe ≈øtood, yet met with ≈ømall Encouragement, managed his bu≈øine≈øs very meanly, fought Cowardly, and in a Month's time was utterly ruined and broken, Him≈øelf taken, his Son Charles (as was thought) Dead, and all his Company broken. He was executed on the Fir≈øt of July, 1685.

On June the 13th. the Duke of Monmouth, with two or three ≈ømall Ve≈ø≈øels, loaded with a good quantity of Arms, and a few Men, Landed at Lyme in Dor≈øet-≈øhire. But again≈øt him al≈øo the Parliament unanimou≈øly joyned with the King, and giving Him Money to rai≈øe an Army, Declared the Duke of Monmouth Traytor by Act of Parliament. But the Duke encrea≈øing his Army mightily at Taunton in Somer≈øet-≈øhire; managed his Affairs with a notable Conduct and
Courage: But finally at Wells his Army beginning to Plunder, and to break out into Debauchery, he ≈øoon after Peri≈øhed in a Pitch't Battel, ≈øome Three miles from Bridgewater; where being wor≈øted for want of good Hor≈øe-men. His Foot fought well, until overpowered by the King's Cannons, and His Hor≈øe and Foot all together upon them, the Field was lo≈øt; and ≈øoon after the Duke was Taken, July the 8th. being hid in a Ditch; and being brought to London, he was Beheaded on Tower-Hill: the 15th. of July, 1685. But the L‚Äîd G‚Äîy being al≈øo Taken, Confe≈ø≈øed the Confederates, and was Saved.

On July the 12th. was a day of Thank≈øgiving for the Succe≈øs of the≈øe Victories. Richard Goodenough was al≈øo Taken, who after confe≈ø≈øed the Accomplices, and ≈øaved his Life. But Fergu≈øon E≈øcaped. Major Wildman, Mr. Speke, Mr. Trenchard, and others. The Lord Delamere, Earl of Stamford, and Lord Brandon, were made Pri≈øoners.

From the≈øe ≈øtirs of Civil Wars, it came to pa≈øs that a ≈øtanding Army was ever after kept up by the King, and the Parliament Adjourned and Prorogued from time to time, it was paid out of the King's own Revenues. And hence Popery encrea≈øed with much advance, the Queen and one Father Petre, much ≈øpurring on.

On November the 9th. the Parliament met at Westmin≈øter, according to Adjournment; at what time the King excu≈øing His Standing-Army kept up, and ≈øeveral Officers allowed again≈øt Law, who had not taken the Te≈øt. The Parliament not plea≈øed herewith, were ≈øoon Prorogued.
On March the 11th. came forth His Maje≈øties Proclamation of General Pardon, not without many Exceptions.

1686. In the Army Popi≈øh Officers by degrees filled all vacant Places: As al≈øo French and Iri≈øh Popi≈øh Souldiers mingled in mo≈øt Troops and Companies. Papi≈øts al≈øo were admitted into Privy-Council; were made Judges, Sheriffs and Ju≈øtices, without taking the Te≈øt. And in February, 1686. the Earl of Tyrconnel a great Papi≈øt, Succeeded the Earl of Clarendon, Lieutenant of Ireland. And the Earl of Roche≈øter
refu≈øing to become a Papi≈øt, was put out of Place of High Trea≈øurer.

On February the 24th. was Publi≈øhed His Maje≈øties Proclamation for Liberty of Con≈øcience to Papi≈øts, and all others as could be tru≈øted in the Kingdom of Scotland. For which the Lords of the Privy-Council of that Kingdom, returned their Thanks. Thus His Maje≈øty by uniting the Popi≈øh and Presbyterian Intere≈øt in Scotland, began to le≈ø≈øen the Authority of the then pre≈øent e≈øtabli≈øhed Church by Prote≈øtant Bi≈øhops.

By this time the Deputy of Ireland being become a Papi≈øt, and much of the Council; the Army there; the Sheriffs, Judges and Ju≈øtices al≈øo being mo≈øtly Popi≈øh, or Popi≈øhly affected, Per≈øons in Popi≈øh Rebells E≈øtates began to be thru≈øt out apace, even by Law too, by means of tho≈øe Judges and Sheriffs; and Popi≈øh Robbers al≈øo multiplied, in≈øomuch as little ≈øafety for Prote≈øtants began to appear in that Kingdom. To quiet which la≈øt Oppre≈ø≈øion, came forth the Proclamation from the Deputy, February the 21≈øt.

On March the 18th. His Maje≈øty declared His intention to grant Liberty of Con≈øcience unto all Per≈øons of what Per≈øwa≈øion ≈øoever: And the better to Father His de≈øign, He Prorogued the Parliament to November 87. And on April the 4th. 1687, His Maje≈øties Declaration to all His loving Subjects for Liberty of Con≈øcience came forth.

Hence followed a crowd of Congratulatory Addre≈ø≈øes, from all ≈øorts of Di≈ø≈øenters. The fir≈øt who began this Holy Dance after His Maje≈øties Pipe, was a great number of Anabapti≈øts in and about London; and being delivered by ≈øeveral of the Chief of them, April the 14th. was called,
The Humble Addre≈øs of divers of Your Maje≈øties Subjects in and about the City of London, commonly called Anabapti≈øts; and ≈øaith,

WE Your Maje≈øties mo≈øt Humble and Loyal Sabjects, who have been of a Long time great Sufferers, by the ≈øevere Execution of Poenal Laws about matters of Religion, (unto which for Con≈øcience ≈øake we could not conform) cannot ≈øufficiently pay tho≈øe acknowledgments we owe to Your Maje≈øty for your late Mo≈øt Gracious Declaration, whereby we are not only delivered from
our pa≈øt Distre≈ø≈øes, and our Families from Ruine, but are al≈øo allowed the free exerci≈øe of our Religion; which is dearer to us than any Worldly Enjoyment.

p.hi: Great Sir, 'tis the fen≈øe of this invaluable Favour, and benefit derived to Us from Your Royal Clemency, that compels us once more to Prostrate our ≈øelves at Your Majestics Feet, with the tender of our most humble Thanks for that Peace and Liberty which both we and all other Di≈ø≈øen ‚Ä¢ ers do now enjoy; and rest confident of, under Your most Gracious Protection.

And being our ≈øelves most firmly re≈øolved (as in Con≈øcience bound) to endeavour to the utmost to give that proof of our Duty and Fidelity to Your Majesty, that you may never have occa≈øion to repent of Your Princely favour towards us. We cannot but rest confident, That ≈øuch demonstrations as the≈øe of Your Majesties tender care of the Pro≈øperity and quiet of Your Peaceable Subjects of all ≈øorts, (though differing in ≈øome Sentiments of Religion) will ≈øo ab≈øolutely command the Hearts of them all, that the only Emulation among them will be, who may approve them≈øelves best worthy of your Majesties favour, and contribute most towards the glory and happine≈øs of your Reign.

div.p: And that God Almighty by pouring out His ≈øignal Ble≈ø≈øings upon Your Majesty, Your Royal Posterity, Government, and People, will be plea≈øed to convince the whole World of the Wi≈ødom and truth of Your Majesties Sentiments, &c.]
Such were the whileom thoughts of the Anabaptists, of King James, notwith≈øtanding all His endeavours of advancing Popery, who appeared in this Addre≈øs,

A ≈øort of People avowing them≈øelves ≈øo exceedingly obliged to King James for favours done them, that their utmo≈øt proof of Duty and Fidelity to His Maje≈øty, can never enough ≈øatisfie; until They give Him occa≈øion never to repent of tho≈øe princely favours to them. Which if ≈øo, then either by this Addre≈øs they think them≈øelves bound in Con≈øcience to adventure their Lives to Re≈øtore Him again to His Throne: (for otherwi≈øe he mu≈øt needs repent of His Princely favours to them, in vain be≈øtowed:) Or el≈øe they have hereby declared them≈øelves, a company of meer empty flattering Sycophants, promi≈øing that which they
never intended. And now was it true as is ≈øaid in the Addre≈øs, then are they them≈øelves the Men bound to bring in King James, again≈øt all ≈øen≈øe of the Opinion of His mo≈øt Excellent Maje≈øty King William, in His Declaration expre≈ø≈øed, and of the late Parliament, in declaring the Government of the Kingdom by King James to be Forfeited, by rea≈øon of Mi≈ø-government. Or if otherwi≈øe, (they ≈øay what they never intended.) Then is no Credit to be given to any thing they ≈øay; their Tongues are no Slander; the Anabaptists in and about London, are a Profligate People, of the Sperm of John of Leydon and Knipperdoling; a company of branded Hypocrites, never to be believed or tru≈øted.

They pretend to have an ab≈øolute Confidence in King James, as to His tender care of the Peace and quiet of His Subjects; they pretend to ≈øtrive again≈øt all Di≈ø≈øenters with Emulation, to do more for Him than all of them. They pretend to be bound to Wi≈øh, Pray, and Fight, and to do all that may be done, that His Maje≈øty and the Prince of Wales His Son, and His Government may be Ble≈ø≈øed. And ≈øo by con≈øequence they mu≈øt hold, that all oppo≈øers ought to be Accur≈øed. And yet the≈øe Men cry'd out again≈øt the late choo≈øers of New Members, [That they would bring in King James again.]

On May the 10th. was pre≈øented to the King, [The mo≈øt Humble Addre≈øs of the Anabapti≈øts in Leice≈øter-≈øhire.] Wherein the≈øe al≈øo acknowledge as the former, Their Thankfulne≈øs for the King's Declaration; and promi≈øing mo≈øt faithfully and ambitiou≈øly to Serve Him with their Obedience and Loyalty in all ways to ihe be≈øt of His Advantage; Praying for Him and His Po≈øterity. And on May the 14th. came in more of the ≈øame from Exeter in the ≈øame County.

On May the 17th. was Pre≈øented the Humble Addre≈øs of the Independents and Anabaptists of Glouce≈øter-≈øhire, Magnifying His Maje≈øties Wi≈ødom and Clemency with Hyperbolical Language, ≈øtiling Him the Rightful Father of His Dominions; Praying Him there may be a Total Aboli≈øhment of the Poenal Statutes concerning Religion, and promi≈øing Him
Exemplary Loyalty; and concluding with [Long Live and Reign King James the Just.]

On May the 21≈øt. was Pre≈øented [The Humble Addre≈øs of the Anabapti≈øts of Stafford, Derby and Nottingham ≈øhires] promi≈øing Their utmo≈øt Loyalty to Him, even unto the making of Him Great throughout all the World. And at the ≈øame time came forth another Addre≈øs of the Anabaptists of Che-≈øhire, Shrop-≈øhire and Stafford-≈øhire, ≈øtiling His Maje≈øty, A Prince by Heaven de≈øigned for the highe≈øt Pattern of Royal Goodne≈øs and true Policy; and promi≈øing to ≈øerve Him with ≈øuch ready Obedience and stedfast Loyalty, to the utmost of their Capacity, in their Station, as it ≈øhall not be po≈ø≈øible for any other Subjects to exceed.
On May the 28th. was pre≈øented to His Maje≈øty the Humble Addre≈øs of the Anabaptists of the City of Bristol; acknowledging, promi≈øing, and wi≈øhing much after the manner as tho≈øe before.

On June the 18th. was Pre≈øented the Humble Addre≈øs of the Anabaptists of Kent, acknowledging, promi≈øing and wi≈øhing like their preceeding Brethren; acknowledging the King, though a (Zealous Papist) yet the most tender and affectionate Prince that ever ≈øway'd the Scepter of His Empire; out-doing all expectation and de≈øert of His Subjects; promi≈øing Submi≈ø≈øion to Him under God, and that unfeignedly, in all things commanded them by Him; Praying that God may grant Him what≈øoever may be needful, for His then pre≈øent and future Happine≈øs.

On June the 29th. was Pre≈øented to His Maje≈øty the Humble Addre≈øs of the Anabaptists of Middle≈øex, Hertford, Bucks, Oxon, Warwick, Northampton, Lincoln, Huntington, Bedford, Cambridge, E≈ø≈øex, Kent Surry, Su≈ø≈øex, Southampton and Dor≈øet-≈øhires, Confirming with very Hyperbolical Compliments, all things afore promi≈øed and owned by the re≈øt of Their preceding Brethren.

And after all the≈øe was pre≈øented, yet one more Humble Addre≈øs of the Anabaptists of Oxford, Abbington, and Wantage, with the ≈øame Flatteries and Warranties as their Fellows. They had once afore Addre≈ø≈øed in that of the
Counties of Oxon and Berks: But it ≈øeems the≈øe Anabaptisto-Papists could not re≈øt ≈øo without a peculiar application, ≈øo proud it ≈øeems they were of their Intere≈øt in a Popi≈øh Prince.

And by all the≈øe Addre≈ø≈øes, it appears plainly, that not only the mo≈øt part, if not all the Anabaptists in and about London, but all over England, have voluntarily and freely engaged them≈øelves unto their utmo≈øt to aid and a≈ø≈øi≈øt King James in taking off the Test and all Poenal Laws; and by con≈øequence to open the ancient Floud gates of Stoppage, and to let in an Inundation of Popery, to over-run and drown not only the Church of England, but al≈øo the whole Kingdom, with an overflow of Popi≈øh Oppre≈ø≈øions.
